Laundry detergent is typically made up of a combination of several different ingredients, including:

1. Surfactants: These are the primary cleaning agents in laundry detergent. Surfactants help to remove dirt and stains from clothing by reducing the surface tension of water and allowing it to penetrate the fabric more easily. Examples of surfactants commonly used in laundry detergent include sodium lauryl sulfate, sodium laureth sulfate, and linear alkylbenzene sulfonate.
2. Builders: Builders are added to laundry detergent to enhance the effectiveness of the surfactants. They help to soften water and remove minerals and other impurities that can interfere with the cleaning process. Common builders include sodium tripolyphosphate, sodium carbonate, and zeolites.
3. Enzymes: Enzymes are added to some laundry detergents to help break down protein-based stains such as blood and grass. Protease, amylase, and lipase are examples of enzymes commonly used in laundry detergent.
4. Optical brighteners: Optical brighteners are chemicals that absorb ultraviolet light and emit blue light, which can make whites appear brighter and colors more vivid. These are often added to laundry detergent to enhance the appearance of clothing.
5. Fragrances: Many laundry detergents contain fragrances to give clothes a fresh, clean scent. These fragrances may be synthetic or derived from natural sources.
6. Fillers: Fillers are added to some laundry detergents to increase the volume of the product and make it appear more substantial. Common fillers include sodium sulfate and sodium chloride.

The exact composition of laundry detergent can vary depending on the brand and type of detergent, as well as the country where it is sold. Some detergents may also contain additional ingredients such as fabric softeners or color-safe bleach.
